snippet: As the debate over military action in Syria has unfolded in the West, Iraqis see the fate of the two countries as inextricably intertwined.
abstract: Iraq's painful history with American military intervention is providing a counternarrative to those who support a Syria intervention; British Parliament, haunted by intelligence failures in Iraq, has voted against strikes on Syria, and, for the same reason, polls show American public is hesitant to back a new military strike in the Middle East.

byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi contributed reporting from Baghdad, and Michael R. Gordon from Washington.

lead_paragraph: As the debate over military action in Syria has unfolded in the West, Iraqis see the fate of the two countries as inextricably intertwined.

headline.main: Iraqis, Looking Across Border, See Replays of Past and Fears for the Future
headline.print_headline: Iraqis, Looking Across Border, See Replays of Past and Fears for the Future
